article.description:
Connecticut showed just how dominant its defense
can be.
article.headline: Huskies hold Pioneers to just 16 percent shooting
article.linkText: No. 4 UConn has its way in ripping Denver 85-29
article.story:
HONOLULU (AP) -- Connecticut showed just how dominant its defense
can be.

	   The Huskies (No. 4 ESPN/USA Today; No. 5 Associated Press) held Denver to 16 percent shooting
(9-for-55) in an 85-29 victory Friday night in the first round of
the Rainbow Wahine Classic.

	   Connecticut (3-0) will play Hawaii (3-0) in the semifinals Saturday. The Rainbow Wahine beat Gonzaga 71-61 earlier Friday
night.

	   ''Our focus of the game is defense,'' said Barbara Turner, who
scored 12 points off the bench for the Huskies. ''We did a good job
switching up our defense, giving them different looks and rotating
on defense.''

	   Denver (0-3) struggled to find the basket. The Pioneers missed
their first 19 field-goal attempts until Ashley Atkinson's
3-pointer with more than seven minutes left in the first half.

	   The Huskies' defense allowed just one more field goal as Denver
shot only 6.9 percent (2-for-29) in the half.

	   ''We had open shots, had shots where we wanted our players to
take in certain spots,'' Denver coach Pam Tanner said. ''We just
didn't get a basket.''

	   Despite the offensive struggle, Tanner felt her team did well on
defense in the first half.

	   ''We took some things away from Connecticut and they came back
and made adjustments,'' she said.

   The Huskies outscored Denver 20-5 to start the second half.
Leading by as many as 56 points, the Huskies got a chance to change
things up.

	   ''You try to slow it, work on things you worked on in practice
or things you haven't worked on,'' said Diana Taurasi, who scored
16 points. ''We did some things we didn't do earlier in the year.
We trapped a little more, just try some different things out.''

	   Nicole Wolff scored 12 points and Ashley Battle added 10 for
Connecticut.

	   ''Our defense has been good all year long,'' UConn coach Geno
Auriemma said. ''We are a good defensive team and we're
communicating well now.''

	   While the Huskies had their way against Denver, Auriemma knows
things will change in the next two tournament games.

	   ''Our strength right now is our perimeter players, that's where
we're doing most of our work right now,'' he said. ''But in the
next two days, we have to figure a way to score inside.''

	   Amber Johnson and Ragan Neblett each had six points for Denver.
